title: Infinite Limits from Positive Integers
text: Use the table to guide your answer.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Positive Even or Odd Integer
text: Is $$n$$ an even or odd integer?

subHints.title: Determining $$n$$
subHints.text: Using the function $$lim_x$$ → a 1/(x - a)**n, what is $$n$$ in $$lim_x$$ → -3**+ 1/(x + 3)**4?

title: Finding $$lim_x$$ → -3**+ 1/(x + 3)**4
text: Given that $$n$$ is a positive even integer, what is the limit?

title: Explanation
text: From the function $$lim_x$$ → a 1/(x - a)**n, we know that $$n$$ $$=$$ $$4$$ in $$lim_x$$ → -3**+ 1/(x + 3)**4. According to the Infinite Limits from Positive Integers Theorem, if $$n$$ is a positive even integer, then $$lim_x$$ → a 1/(x - a)**n $$=$$ $$+\infty$$. Since $$4$$ is a positive even integer, this means that $$lim_x$$ → -3**+ 1/(x + 3)**4 $$=$$ $$+\infty$$.
